snippet: Jonathan Pryce plays a tramp aided and tormented by two brothers in a revival of Harold Pinter’s classic 1960 play “The Caretaker” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
abstract: Charles Isherwood reviews Harold Pinter play The Caretaker, directed by Christopher Morahan and starring Jonathan Pryce at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Photos (M)
lead_paragraph: ''What am I going to do?'' cries the scruffy old fellow in a stricken voice, his imploring eyes fixed on the back of the younger man before him. ''What shall I do? Where am I going to go?'' Answers never come in ''The Caretaker,'' Harold Pinter's classic 1960 play about the peculiar relations among a tramp and two brothers in a cluttered room in a dilapidated London house. But like many other unanswered questions in Pinter plays, the old man's plea takes on a weird, terrible urgency. Acrid comedy has suddenly curdled into something closer to tragedy, and you can't really put your finger on exactly when or precisely why.
